title: Truth and Lies in Latin Prose
yc_attrs: This course can be applied towards the Language (5) Yale College distributional requirement.
description:
This bridge course is intended for students expecting to matriculate into advanced Latin seminars in the next term. In this course, we explore questions related to the nature and value of truth as it existed for ancient writers of Latin prose. The backbone of our investigation is the close reading of selections from Latin writers across three different genres: history (Livy), oratory (Cicero), and letters (Pliny). We supplement our reading with occasional secondary sources that throw into relief the potentially different ways in which fact and fiction operated in the ancient world. Over the course of the term, we return to two central questions: 1) What is the relationship between truth and genre?  2) How did ancient audiences experience truth? In exploring these questions, we grapple with the function of truth in our own society, and reflect on the complex and often problematic legacy of truth as standard of writing.

Students are expected to have completed L4 instruction through Yale, or to have been placed at a comparable reading level by the DUS or instructor.
